title: The Constitutional Convention
description: The Grand Experiment. Delegates meet in secret to forge a new government.

title: Virginia Plan
description: Edmund Randolph, the Governor of Virginia, opened the main business of the Convention by presenting 15 resolutions drafted primarily by James Madison. Known as the Virginia Plan, it proposed a radical restructuring of the government: replacing the loose Confederation with a supreme National Government composed of three branches (Legislative, Executive, Judicial) and a bicameral Congress where representation was based on population. This immediately shifted the debate from 'amending' the Articles to 'abolishing' them.

tooltip.Virginia: Edmund Randolph and James Madison were from Virginia.

title: Committee of the Whole Formed
description:
The Convention resolved itself into a 'Committee of the Whole' to debate the Virginia Plan freely. This procedural move allowed delegates to vote tentatively without their decisions being binding, encouraging candor.

Immediately, the Convention faced a defining moment: Edmund Randolph moved to postpone 'amending' the Articles and instead proposed that 'a national government ought to be established consisting of a supreme Legislative, Executive and Judiciary.' This radical pivot—from a loose federation to a supreme nation—passed 6 votes to 1.

title: Single Executive
description: The delegates struggled to define the presidency, fearing a monarchy but wanting a strong leader. The Convention agreed (7 - 3) to have a Single Executive rather than a committee.

title: Three-Fifths Compromise
description: James Wilson, seconded by Charles Pinckney, moved to define the ratio of representation. This motion proposed that representation would include the whole number of free citizens plus three-fifths of "all other persons"

title: New Jersey Plan
description:
After weeks of debate dominated by the Virginia Plan, the small states struck back. William Paterson of New Jersey introduced a counter-proposal drafted by a coalition of delegates from New Jersey, New York, Connecticut, and Delaware.

The 'New Jersey Plan' proposed merely amending the Articles of Confederation rather than scrapping them. It retained a unicameral (one-house) legislature with equal voting rights ('one state, one vote') but granted Congress new powers to tax and regulate commerce. This established the central ideological battle of the summer: State Sovereignty vs. National Supremacy.

tooltip.New Jersey: William Paterson introduced the plan, arguing that the Convention had no authority to destroy the Articles of Confederation, only to revise them.

title: Rejection of the New Jersey Plan
description:
After days of intense comparison between the two plans, James Madison delivered a crushing speech analyzing the New Jersey Plan, arguing it would fail to secure the Union or prevent states from violating treaties. 

Persuaded by Madison's logic, the Convention voted 7 states to 3 (with Maryland divided) to reject the New Jersey Plan and proceed with the Virginia Plan. By doing so, the delegates officially decided that the Articles of Confederation could not be fixed and must be abolished in favor of a new national government.

tooltip.New Jersey: William Paterson saw his plan defeated, but his group had successfully forced the Convention to acknowledge that the small states would not submit to total domination.

title: Lansing, Mason, & Martin Debate
description: Following the defeat of the New Jersey Plan, the delegates were debating the first resolution of the Virginia Plan. The tension centered on whether the States should remain sovereign in a confederation, or become a consolidated national government. The delegates voted to reject the Articles of Confederation which marked the last significant attempt to save the Articles of Confederation

tooltip.New York: John Lansing of New York, a staunch defender of state sovereignty proposed to keep the structure of the Articles of Confederation where the legislature was a single-house in which states had equal votes rather than adopting the Virginia Plan's bicameral system based on population.
tooltip.Virginia: George Mason of Virginia argued that the Confederation was critically flawed because it operated on states, not individuals. He famously asked if the delegates were willing to give the power of the "sword and the purse" to a single legislative body that was not directly chosen by the people. He argued the new government needed to operate directly on citizens to avoid this.
tooltip.Maryland: Luther Martin of Maryland, known for his intense and often lengthy speeches defending state rights, supported Lansing's motion because he feared the larger states (like Virginia and Pennsylvania) would dominate the smaller states in the proposed national government.

title: The Connecticut Compromise
description: Under the Virginia plan, the number of officials in both houses would be allocated to each state proportional to its population. Less populous states were afraid that such an arrangement would result in their voices and interests being drowned out by the larger states. In response, Roger Sherman proposed to keep a bicameral legislature, but keep one proportional to population, and in the second branch of the Legislature, have each State an equal vote.

title: Mason's Objections
description: George Mason writes his formal objections, famously declaring: 'There is no Declaration of Rights.' He fears the new government will become a monarchy or aristocracy.

tooltip.Virginia: Mason demands a Bill of Rights.

title: Signing of the Constitution
description: The Convention concludes. 39 delegates sign the Constitution. The document is forwarded to the Confederation Congress.

title: NC Delegates Report to Gov
description: The North Carolina delegates write to Governor Richard Caswell, explaining the compromises made and urging consideration of the new plan.

title: Congress Reads Constitution
description: The Confederation Congress in New York officially receives the proposed Constitution. The text is read aloud to the members.

title: Congress Debates
description: Debate begins in the Confederation Congress on whether to send the Constitution to the states for ratification.

title: Pennsylvania Calls Convention
description: In a rush to be first, the Pennsylvania Assembly votes to call a state ratifying convention, despite protests from the minority who wanted more time to review.

tooltip.Pennsylvania: The first state to call a convention.

title: James Wilson's Speech
description: James Wilson delivers a famous speech in the State House Yard in Philadelphia, forcefully defending the Constitution and denying the need for a Bill of Rights.

title: R.H. Lee to Randolph
description: Richard Henry Lee, in New York, writes to Edmund Randolph expressing serious doubts, organizing the Anti-Federalist opposition.

title: Massachusetts Calls Convention
description: The Massachusetts legislature votes to convene a ratifying convention, setting the stage for a contentious battle in Boston.

title: Georgia Calls Convention
description: Georgia, needing strong federal protection against Creek uprisings on its border, moves quickly to call a convention.

title: Remarks on PA Convention
description: Pamphlets begin circulating in Pennsylvania, criticizing the hasty call for a convention and the 'aristocratic' nature of the new plan.

title: Virginia Calls Convention
description: Virginia, the largest and most influential state, officially calls for a convention. The stage is set for a clash between Madison and Henry.

title: NJ Calls Convention
description: New Jersey legislature calls for a state ratifying convention.

title: PA Elects Delegates
description: Pennsylvania elects 69 delegates to their ratifying convention.

title: DE Calls Convention
description: Delaware calls for a state ratifying convention.

title: CT Elects Delegates
description: Connecticut elects 168 delegates.

title: MA Elections Begin
description: Massachusetts begins the election of 355 delegates.

title: PA Convention Convenes
description: The Pennsylvania ratifying convention officially convenes.

title: DE Elects Delegates
description: Delaware elects 30 delegates (Nov 22-26).

title: James Wilson Speech
description: James Wilson delivers a significant speech at the Pennsylvania Convention.

title: MD Calls Convention
description: Maryland calls for a state ratifying convention.

title: NJ Elects Delegates
description: New Jersey elects 38 delegates (Nov 27-Dec 1).

title: Remarks on PA Convention
description: Remarks recorded regarding the ongoing Pennsylvania Ratifying Convention.

title: McHenry's Speech
description: James McHenry speaks to the Maryland State House of Delegates.

title: Luther Martin's Speech
description: Luther Martin speaks to the Maryland State House of Delegates, opposing strong federal power.

title: PA Convention Speech (AM)
description: Morning session speech to the Pennsylvania Conventions.

title: PA Convention Speech (PM)
description: Afternoon session speech to the Pennsylvania Conventions.

title: DE Convention Convenes
description: The Delaware ratifying convention convenes.

title: GA Elects Delegates
description: Georgia elects 26 delegates (Dec 4-5).

title: NC Calls Convention
description: North Carolina calls for a state ratifying convention.

title: Delaware Ratifies
description: Delaware becomes the FIRST state to ratify the Constitution, doing so unanimously (30-0).

title: NJ Convention Convenes
description: The New Jersey ratifying convention convenes.

title: Pennsylvania Ratifies
description: Pennsylvania becomes the 2nd state to ratify the Constitution with a vote of 46-23.

title: NH Calls Convention
description: New Hampshire calls for a state ratifying convention.

title: New Jersey Ratifies
description: New Jersey becomes the 3rd state to ratify the Constitution, doing so unanimously (38-0).

title: PA Minority Dissent
description: The Dissent of the Minority of the Convention of Pennsylvania is published, outlining Anti-Federalist concerns.

title: Yates & Lansing Dissent
description: Robert Yates and John Lansing publish their Reasons of Dissent regarding the New York delegation.

title: GA Convention Meets
description: The Georgia ratifying convention meets on Christmas Day.

title: Georgia Ratifies
description: Georgia becomes the 4th state to ratify the Constitution, doing so unanimously (26-0).

title: NH Elects Delegates
description: New Hampshire elects 110 delegates to their convention.

title: Georgia Ratifies
description: Georgia becomes the 4th state to ratify the Constitution. The vote is unanimous (26-0), driven by the state's need for strong federal protection against Creek conflicts on their frontier.

title: Connecticut Convention Convenes
description: Delegates gather in Hartford. The debate is largely favorable, led by Oliver Ellsworth who helped craft the Great Compromise.

title: Ellsworth & Wadsworth Speeches
description: Key speeches define the debate. Oliver Ellsworth argues for Union, while James Wadsworth questions the power of the sword and purse being held by the same body.

title: Connecticut Ratifies
description: Connecticut becomes the 5th state to ratify. The vote is decisive (128-40), affirming the state's role in architecting the compromise that made the Constitution possible.

title: Massachusetts Election Conclusion
description: Elections conclude for the 355 delegates to the Massachusetts convention. The sheer size of the delegation reflects the deep divisions in the state following Shays' Rebellion.

title: Charles Turner Speech
description: In the Massachusetts convention, Charles Turner gives a voice to the Anti-Federalist fears, worrying that the new government lacks sufficient checks against tyranny.

title: South Carolina Calls Convention
description: The South Carolina legislature votes to call a state ratifying convention, setting the stage for debates over slavery and representation.

title: Massachusetts Compromise Proposed
description: A turning point in history. To win over skeptical Anti-Federalists, Federalists propose ratifying the Constitution *with* recommended amendments (a Bill of Rights). This strategy becomes the model for remaining states.

title: New York Calls Convention
description: The New York legislature, deeply divided between Hamilton's Federalists and Clinton's Anti-Federalists, issues a call for a convention.

title: Massachusetts Ratifies
description: Massachusetts becomes the 6th state to ratify, but by a razor-thin margin (187-168). The victory is secured only by the promise of future amendments.

title: Jefferson to Donald
description: From Paris, Thomas Jefferson writes to Alexander Donald, expressing cautious optimism about the Constitution but insisting on the necessity of a Bill of Rights.

tooltip.Virginia: Jefferson urges a Bill of Rights.

title: NH Convention Adjourns
description: Trouble for the Federalists. The New Hampshire convention, realizing they lack the votes to ratify, votes 56-51 to adjourn until June rather than risk a rejection.

title: Rhode Island Rejects Convention
description: Rhode Island, the outlier, refuses to even call a ratifying convention. Instead, they hold a popular referendum where the Constitution is overwhelmingly rejected.

title: North Carolina Elects Delegates
description: North Carolina holds elections for their convention. The results lean heavily Anti-Federalist, signaling a difficult road ahead for ratification.

title: Maryland Convention Convenes
description: Delegates meet in Annapolis. Despite a vocal Anti-Federalist minority, the Federalist organization dominates the proceedings.

title: Maryland Ratifies
description: Maryland becomes the 7th state to ratify. The vote is a comfortable 63-11, restoring Federalist momentum after the stumble in New Hampshire.

title: New York Elections
description: New York concludes elections for delegates. Governor George Clinton's Anti-Federalist forces win a significant majority of the seats.

title: South Carolina Convention
description: The South Carolina ratifying convention convenes in Charleston to debate the Constitution.

title: South Carolina Ratifies
description: South Carolina becomes the 8th state to ratify the Constitution, voting 149-73 in favor.

title: Virginia Convention
description: The Virginia ratifying convention convenes. The debate here is critical, featuring heavyweights like Madison, Henry, and Mason.

title: Patrick Henry Speaks
description: Leading Anti-Federalist Patrick Henry delivers a passionate speech arguing that the new Constitution endangers state sovereignty and individual liberty.

title: George Mason's Plea
description: George Mason argues that without a Bill of Rights, the Constitution grants too much power to the central government.

tooltip.Virginia: Mason demands a Bill of Rights.

title: Pendleton Supports
description: Edmund Pendleton, president of the convention, speaks in favor of the judiciary and the stability the Constitution offers.

title: New York Convention
description: The New York convention convenes in Poughkeepsie. The Anti-Federalists hold a significant majority at the start.

title: New Hampshire Reconvenes
description: After adjourning in February to avoid rejection, the New Hampshire convention reconvenes for a second session.

title: Melancton Smith Speaks
description: Melancton Smith, a moderate Anti-Federalist leader in NY, debates representation, arguing the proposed House is too small to represent the common people.

title: Hamilton Defends
description: Alexander Hamilton delivers a major speech defending the structure of the new government and the necessity of a strong executive.

title: New Hampshire Ratifies
description: A historic milestone. New Hampshire becomes the 9th state to ratify (57-47), satisfying the requirement to put the Constitution into legal effect.

title: Virginia Ratifies
description: In a close 89-79 vote, Virginia ratifies the Constitution but proposes 20 amendments to protections rights, heavily influenced by the Anti-Federalists.

title: Congress Accepts
description: The Confederation Congress, meeting in New York, officially acknowledges that 9 states have ratified and begins planning for the first presidential election.

title: North Carolina Convenes
description: North Carolina's convention meets. The mood is heavily skeptical of the new central government.

title: New York Ratifies
description: Following news of Virginia and New Hampshire, New York narrowly ratifies (30-27) with a long list of proposed amendments, knowing they cannot remain outside the union.

title: North Carolina Rejects
description: By a vote of 184-84, North Carolina declines to ratify the Constitution until a Bill of Rights is added, leaving them outside the new Union for now.

title: NC Convention Convenes
description: North Carolina's second ratifying convention meets in Fayetteville. Having previously rejected the Constitution for lacking a Bill of Rights, the delegates gather again now that the amendments have been proposed.

title: North Carolina Ratifies
description: North Carolina becomes the 12th state to ratify the Constitution (194-77). The promise of a Bill of Rights secures the necessary votes, bringing the state officially into the new Union.

title: RI Convention Convenes
description: Rhode Island, the last holdout and the only state to boycott the Constitutional Convention, finally calls a convention in Newport. They face immense pressure, including threats from the U.S. Senate to treat them as a foreign nation and ban trade.

title: Rhode Island Ratifies
description: The Union is complete. Rhode Island ratifies by the narrowest of margins (34-32), officially bringing the last of the original thirteen colonies under the new Constitution.
